webTitle: Brexit: blow to May’s authority as MPs reject her motion by 303 votes to 258 - as it happened

fields.headline: Brexit: blow to May’s authority as MPs reject her motion by 303 votes to 258 - as it happened
fields.standfirst:
Rolling coverage of the day’s political developments as they happen, including the latest Commons debate and votes on what should happen next with Brexit

  • Full story: May defeated after ERG Tories abstain
  • Interactive: How did your MP vote?
  • Exclusive: Corbyn to hold talks with Barnier next week
  • What does May’s defeat mean? Snap analysis
fields.trailText: Rolling coverage of the day’s political developments as they happen, including the latest Commons debate and votes on what should happen next with Brexit
fields.body:
8.50pm GMT

Closing summary

We’re going to close down this live blog now, so thanks for reading and commenting. Here’s a summary of the day:

  • Theresa May suffered a humiliating defeat in the Commons over her approach to Brexit. MPs rejected her motion by a majority of 45 and, while the defeat will have no practical effect, it will make it harder for the prime minister to argue to the EU that she has a Commons majority behind her Brexit strategy.
  • A significant number of the most hardline Eurosceptics in May’s own party abstained on the vote. The hard Brexit-supporting ERG were unhappy that the government’s motion appeared to rule out a no-deal Brexit. That led some of the more pro-EU Tories to warn her she cannot rely on the right of her party.
  • Reacting to the defeat, Downing Street chose to point the finger at the Labour leader, Jeremy Corbyn, who opposed the government’s motion. Number 10 said Corbyn had “put partisan considerations ahead of the national interest” and voted to “make no deal more likely”.

If you’d like to read more, my colleagues Rowena Mason and Jessica Elgot have the full story:

Related: Theresa May defeated on Brexit again as ERG Tories abstain

8.21pm GMT

Valentine’s Day plans have not prevented the ERG’s deputy chair, Steve Baker, from responding to Harrington’s comments. This from ITV News’ Paul Brand:

Updated at 8.25pm GMT

8.06pm GMT

The business minister, Richard Harrington, has accused members of the Tory European Research Group (ERG) of “treachery” over Brexit.

Harrington hit out at the ERG, which is headed by Jacob Rees-Mogg, as he suggested members should defect to Nigel Farage’s new party because they are not Conservatives. Referring to the ERG, the minister told the House magazine:

The prime minister has done a pretty good job of standing up to them up till now, but they were drinking champagne to celebrate her losing her deal and I regard that as being treachery.

I read that Nigel Farage is setting up a new party called ‘Brexit’ and, if I were them, I’d be looking at that because that seems to reflect their views more than the Conservative party does.

They should read carefully what that party’s got to offer, because in my view they’re not Conservatives.

There are people who are very solid and stringent in their views and if I were they I would be looking at a party that seems designed for them – Nigel Farage’s party.

Harrington, who backed Remain in the referendum, said it would give the ERG pleasure if ministers who shared his views on Brexit resigned.

If we all resigned what would then happen? If I were in the ERG, it would give me a lot of pleasure to see us resign. But we can’t give in to a minority of a minority, which is what the ERG are.

Harrington also dismissed the so-called Malthouse compromise, which is intended to try to bridge Tory divisions on Brexit.

It’s basically regurgitated Canada Plus, which we know is not at all suited to our close relationship with the European Union, plus a bit of glorified number plate recognition kit, which they’ve got there anyway. I think it’s just fanciful nonsense.

Updated at 8.11pm GMT

7.59pm GMT

Some in her own party are advising Theresa May she cannot rely on the ERG and should find another way altogether. Jessica Elgot has an insight into how Number 10 may be going about plotting its course from here:

7.32pm GMT

Here is some more analysis of the result.

From the Guardian

And here is an extract from the Guardian editorial.

A large part of what is so reckless about this process is that the row between the fanatics and the government centres on rightwing dogmas not facts. At issue this week were the words in the prime minister’s bland motion, part of which reiterated “its support for the approach to leaving the EU expressed by this house on 29 January”. That “approach” to Brexit included the vacuous Graham Brady amendment, which required the government to replace the backstop by alternative arrangements. But the house’s approach on 29 January also included the Caroline Spelman amendment, which rejected leaving the EU with no deal. Both were passed but, to the fanatics, only Brady was acceptable. This explained why, at the very start of Thursday’s debate, the Brexit secretary, Stephen Barclay, had to confirm to David Davis that the UK would be leaving the EU on 29 March if there is – as some fanatics hope – no deal. That brief exchange encapsulated the haplessness of recent Commons Brexit proceedings, because it was both misguided and unavailing. The assurances made no difference. This is hopeless stuff for matters of such importance. It reeks of failure.

From ITV’s Robert Peston

And here is an extract from Peston’s Facebook post.

So this is how it will probably now play out.

On February 27, the PM may finally and pre-emptively – before any vote on the so-called Cooper/Letwin amendment – surrender to MPs’ lobbying and agree to ask the EU for a Brexit delay.

Some of her close associates tell me that she could do this, although it would mean defying all precedent and deliberately facing down her ERG Brexiter MPs - who would go berserk.

The alternative would be for her to continue to maintain a formal position of opposing a delay to Brexit.

What does May's defeat mean? Snap analysis

Some Commons votes have very clear consequences - either legislative or political (like a no-confidence vote). Others are rather harder to interpret. Today’s was very definitely in the second category, but that does not mean it does not matter (calling it “symbolic” does not particularly help) and this may turn out to be a significant moment in the Brexit saga. Here is a snap analysis of what it means.

1) May will find it much harder now to argue that she has got a Commons majority behind her Brexit strategy. Two weeks ago she secured a majority for the Brady amendment. Today’s vote has not entirely reversed that – Brady would probably still pass, if there were another vote today – but it shows that some of the Tories who backed Brady were not willing to to do so if that was combined with a suggestion that a no-deal Brexit should be off the table.

2) The debate showed that MPs were only able to unite behind Brady because they could not agree what it meant. This became apparent during the opening of the debate (see 2.31pm) when Tory Brexiters were saying the Malthouse compromise should be official government policy, but Stephen Barclay, the Brexit secretary, refused to concede this.

3) EU leaders, who were already extremely reluctant to offer much to the UK in terms of backstop concessions because they could not be sure what might get through parliament, will now almost certainly feel even less inclined to engage. It is hard to see the point in doing a deal with a leader who cannot get what she agrees through parliament.

4) New government evidence about how damaging a no-deal Brexit might be will have to be published soon. That was the last-minute concession announced by Chris Heaton-Harris. (See 4.47pm.) If it says what Anna Soubry thinks it will say, this will strengthen the hand of those MPs arguing that no deal should be ruled out – although there is a lot of evidence suggesting that the public at large are less concerned about these warnings.

5) May’s defeat raises questions about the competence of the government’s management of parliamentary business. Leavers and remainers were saying this morning that, if the government had consulted more widely when drafting its motion, the defeat could easily have been averted. (See 11.32am.) And it is also arguable that the government, instead of offering Soubry what she wanted, would have been better letting her put her amendment to a vote. It would have been defeated, but at least it would have lost on an issue where it was willing to lose. On the plus side, there would have been no vote on the main motion, meaning no split with the ERG and no prospect of the vote two weeks ago being arguably reversed. (See 3.39pm.)

6) Today’s votes suggest that the debate due on Wednesday 27 February (see 9.19am) may end up being a decisive moment for Brexit. It is important to remember that today’s debate essentially postponed key decisions; there was no vote on giving parliament the power to rule out a second referendum, and no vote on a second referendum. But those Tories planning to back the Yvette Cooper amendment and bill giving the Commons the power to rule out no deal will be emboldened – especially when they read the Number 10 statement implying May is attentive to MPs who want to keep no deal as an option (see 6.23pm) - and during the debate it became clear that Labour MPs determined to vote for a second referendum won’t wait much longer (eg, see 2.55pm.)

2.31pm GMT

Opening of Brexit debate - summary and analysis

What was significant about the Brady amendment passed two weeks ago is that it managed to unite the Conservative party behind a Brexit proposition. Only eight Tories voted against.

But managing to come up with a Brexit stance acceptable to remainers and leavers in the party is much harder than it looks and, in his speech opening the debate, Stephen Barclay, the Brexit secretary, struggled considerably. He arrived armed with a no-deal assurance intended to go down well with the hardliners in the European Research Group, and some conciliatory language about the so-called Malthouse compromise, which is viewed as the holy grail by some Brexiters. But quite quickly it became apparent that he was not giving them quite as much as they wanted. And, in the second half of his speech, after he tacked towards leave, remainers in the party started standing up in the chamber to complain.

It is not clear yet what will happen in the vote on the main motion, but Nikki da Costa, a former director of legislative affairs at Number 10, concluded after hearing Barclay’s speech that the government was in real trouble.

Sir Keir Starmer, Barclay’s shadow, was responding for Labour and the opening of his speech, which focused on the folly of Theresa May thinking that she will be able to achieve changes to the Brexit deal now which have eluded her for weeks, was excellent. But Labour is also a party deeply divided over Brexit and towards the end he faced strong criticism from some Labour pro-Europeans who want the party to commit to a second referendum now. He was unable to give them the assurances they wanted to hear, just as he also struggled to explain why Labour was at once accepting the need for a backstop while having reservations about it.

Here are the main points.

  • Barclay insisted that the government was willing to leave the EU on 29 March without a deal. Earlier this week Olly Robbins, Theresa May’s chief Brexit adviser, suggested in a conversation overheard in Brussels, that this would not be an option. Barclay was responding to a question from the Brexiter David Davis who asked for an assurance that the UK would still leave on 29 March in the event of May not getting an acceptable deal. Barclay replied:

I’m very happy to give [Davis] that assurance.

This seemed designed to mollify the ERG Brexiters who do not want to back the main government motion because it implicitly endorses the vote two weeks ago ruling out no deal. Davis seemed happy with what he heard.

  • But Barclay refused to say that the Malthouse compromise was now official government policy. Two Tory Brexiters, Charlie Elphicke and Owen Paterson, asked him to give this commitment. Barclay said that May has promised to engage seriously with the plan, and he said this included “investing civil service resource in exploring its viability and its acceptability to the [Northern Ireland] community as a whole”. He also said he had discussed the idea with the EU. But he refused to describe it as official government policy, and he said that Michel Barnier, the EU’s chief Brexit negotiator, had raised doubts about it.
  • Barclay was strongly criticised by Tory remainers for saying a no-deal Brexit remained an option, even though MPs voted to reject it two weeks ago. Justine Greening, the former education secretary, said the government could not “pick and choose” which votes it supported, describing this approach as “fundamentally wrong and anti-democratic”. And Dame Caroline Spelman, the former environment secretary who tabled the motion ruling out no deal passed by MPs two weeks ago, said that if the government did not give that vote as much respect as the vote for the Brady amendment, that would be “contemptuous of this house”.
  • Starmer said the government’s search for an alternative to the backstop was pointless. He told MPs:

The simple and painful truth is this: if there had been a viable alternative to the backstop there would never have been a backstop.

  • He described the Labour amendment as being on putting a “hard stop” on May’s Brexit strategy. He said:

Labour’s amendment today is intended to put a hard stop to running down the clock. It says that on 27 February the government must put a deal to the house for its approval or bring an amendable motion so the house can take control of what happens next and it’s essential that we do so.

Starmer used to be director of public prosecutions and a “hard stop” is a police term for what happens when a car carrying a suspect is halted, often by armed officers. But Labour’s version, presumably, would not involve firearms.

Updated at 7.33pm GMT

1.42pm GMT

Rees-Mogg says Brexiters are 'highly unlikely' to vote against government

According to ITV’s Paul Brand, Jacob Rees-Mogg, the chair of the ERG, is saying Brexiters are unlikely to vote against the government on the main motion tonight. But Brand concedes the ERG has not taken a final position.

It is worth pointing out that “voting against” is not the same as supporting. On the basis of this quote, the ERG could end up abstaining on the main motion, which could lead to the government being defeated.

1.34pm GMT

And this is from Hilary Benn, the Labour chair of the Commons Brexit committee.

1.33pm GMT

This is from the Daily Mail’s Jason Groves.

1.31pm GMT

Ken Clarke, the Tory pro-European, is speaking now.

I will post a summary of the main points from the opening of the debate shortly, and catch up with Clarke speech a bit later.

A European Research Group source says it will be meeting at 4pm to decide how it will vote at 5pm.

(With three amendments, and then a vote on the main motion, all the voting should be over by around 6pm.)

1.26pm GMT

Starmer says further steps should be taken, beyond what is in Labour’s amendment.

He backs the Yvette Cooper amendment and bill designed to allow MPs to vote to rule out a no-deal Brexit.

Labour’s Gareth Snell asks what would happen if article 50 was extended for more than three months. Would the UK participate in the European elections?

Starmer says the EU would agree an extension up to the start of July, because then the UK would not need to participate in those elections. He says it is not policy to participate in them.

1.23pm GMT

Labour’s Ben Bradshaw says the party is leaving it too late to back a people’s vote.

Starmer says Labour put its Brexit plan in its letter to Theresa May. That has been well received by business leaders and by the EU. May has replied in non-committal terms. He says he won’t discuss what is happening in the cross-party talks, because they are confidential.

Labour’s Chris Leslie says, at the party conference, Starmer took the applause when he said a second referendum was an option. Leslie says Labour should commit to one at the next available opportunity.

Starmer says he thinks everyone knows what he thinks about a second referendum.

Updated at 1.23pm GMT

1.18pm GMT

Sarah Wollaston, the Tory pro-European, asks at what point Jeremy Corbyn will unequivocally back a “people’s vote”.

Starmer says the Labour amendment today would put a “hard stop” to the Brexit process. At the point Labour would take a position. It would consider what views were in the Commons.

Updated at 1.19pm GMT

1.16pm GMT

Starmer says the Spelman amendment passed two weeks ago, ruling out no deal, should be just as binding on the government as the Brady amendment.

Phillip Lee, a Conservative pro-European, asks what Labour would do if the UK faces a no-deal Brexit at the end of March.

Starmer says Labour agreed a position at its party conference. He says the party agreed it would do whatever was necessary to avoid a hard deal.

The DUP’s Ian Paisley asks if it is Labour’s position that there must be legally binding changes to the backstop.

Starmer says Labour has concerns about the backstop. But it also accepts that need for a backstop.

Sylvia Hermon, the independent MP from Northern Ireland, says there is confusion about Labour’s position.

Starmer says he knows how important this is. Labour accepts a backstop is inevitable, notwithstanding its concerns.

1.12pm GMT

Starmer says threatening to leave on 29 March without a deal is not a credible negotiating position.

He says MPs have heard the warnings from Airbus and Nissan about the impact of a no-deal. Yesterday Ford said no deal would be “catastrophic” for the car industry.

Alex Chalk, a Tory, says if Labour takes these warnings seriously, it should have voted for May’s deal.

Starmer says Tories did not vote for the deal either. And Conservative MP, including Theresa May, only voted for the Brady amendment because it demanded changes to the deal.

1.09pm GMT

Starmer says Labour’s amendment is designed to put a “hard stop” to Brexit. It says either May has to agree a deal by 27 February, or else the Commons will move on to something else.

1.08pm GMT

Shailesh Vara, a Conservative, says the UK is negotiating the biggest business deal in its history. It has to hold its nerve, and not rule out a no deal, because the EU will give in at the last minute, he says.

Starmer says he wants to let Vara down gently. The UK is just not prepared for a no-deal Brexit, he says. There are people in custody who could not be extradited under a no-deal Brexit.

Starmer says Tories used to complain that publishing impact assessments would undermine the UK’s negotiating position, and they were wrong. They used to complain publishing the legal advice would undermine the UK’s negotiating position, and they were wrong. Now the Tories are saying the same about ruling out a no-deal Brexit.

1.03pm GMT

The SNP’s Stephen Gethins asks if Labour will back the SNP amendment calling three-month extension to article 50 so that a no-deal Brexit can be avoided.

Starmer says he is sympathetic to this argument. He says Labour will be backing the Yvette Cooper amendment (due to be debated on 27 February, not today) designed to allow MPs to vote to block a no-deal Brexit.

On the prospect of May taking the UK out of the EU on 29 March without a deal, he says: “We’ll see about that.”

He says he does not think May would actually agree to a no-deal Brexit.

Labour’s Chuka Umunna says the problem is May’s refusal to face down “the party within a party” that is the ERG.

Starmer agrees.

12.59pm GMT

Starmer says, if alternative to backstop existed, there wouldn't be a backstop

The SNP’s Angus MacNeil says the Malthouse compromise is the “Malthouse fantasy”.

Starmer says the government has not adopted this as its policy position.

The simple and painful truth is this. If there had been a viable alternative to the backstop, there would not have been a backstop.

Starmer says the EU and the UK “searched and searched and searched” for an alternative to the backstop but could not find one.

Updated at 1.04pm GMT

12.58pm GMT

Labour’s Pat McFadden says all these “alternative arrangements” are just “Brexit unicorns”. Isn’t the government just hoping Chancellor Merkel will come to the rescue and throw Ireland under the bus?

Starmer says he agrees.

12.55pm GMT

Starmer says May has spent “weeks and weeks and weeks trying to negotiate changes to the backstop ... and she has got absolutely nowhere”.

He says the idea that the vote on 29 January gave clarity is “for the birds”. Uniting around a proposition that means different things to different people does not help, he says.

He says May has called for either a time limit to the backstop, or a unilateral exit mechanism, or alternative arrangements. The first two options have been repeatedly ruled out by the EU. And the third is undefined.

He says Barclay gave the game away. If the Malthouse compromise was really viable, Barclay would say the government was adopting it as policy.

12.52pm GMT

Sir Keir Starmer, the shadow Brexit secretary, is now responding for Labour.

He says it is obvious what May is up to. She is pretending to make progress, while running down the clock.

He says in December May pulled the vote on her deal, promising to make progress on the backstop.

That was 66 days ago. May went back to the EU, but “returned with nothing”. All she got was “warm words” from the EU, and letter repeating existing commitments.

May lost the vote on 15 January. Then she promised again to get changes to the backstop.

But, when MPs voted on this on 29 January, May voted against the deal she had negotiated, he says.

He says anyone who has spoken to the EU will now how much that did to damage trust.

12.49pm GMT

Barclay says MPs need to give the government more time. It is time for MPs to hold their nerve, he says.

And that is it. He has finished.

12.48pm GMT

The Sun’s Tom Newton Dunn has a good summary of the state of play so far.

Updated at 12.48pm GMT

12.47pm GMT

Barclay says the EU has said it will not re-open the withdrawal agreement. But it has also said that it wants a deal, he says.

Sylvia Hermon, the independent MP from Northern Ireland, asks Barclay to confirm that the government has no intention of replacing the backstop, which is essential for Northern Ireland.

Barclay says the government is discussing what to do next with it.

Owen Paterson, the Tory Brexiter, says the Brady amendment said the backstop should be replaced. Can Barclay confirm the Malthouse compromise is now government policy, and that civil servants will work it up into legally binding text.

Barclay says he has already said the government is taking this proposal, and that it has discussed it with the EU, but that Barnier has doubts about whether it could be implemented on time.

12.43pm GMT

Barclay says the government will get civil servants to look into the viability of using alternative arrangements to replace the backstop.

He says he raised the possibility of using alternative arrangements to replace the backstop in his talks with Michel Barnier. But Barnier was sceptical about whether this could be done in time.

Charlie Elphicke, a Tory Brexiter, asks if the so-called Malthouse compromise is now government policy.

Barclay says he has already taken this forward in his talks with the EU.

Hilary Benn, the Labour chair of the Brexit committee, intervenes. He points out that Donald Tusk said on Twitter yesterday that he had not received concrete proposals from the UK. (See 9.28am.)

Barclay says you should be cautious of what is put on Twitter. He says these ideas have been put forward to the EU.

12.38pm GMT

Dame Caroline Spelman intervenes. She says the government motion endorses the Commons decision from two weeks ago. Two amendments were passed that night – one of which was hers, ruling out a no-deal Brexit. She accuses Barclray of being contemptuous of the views of the Commons.

Barclay says the government respects the views of the house. But he says he was just trying to set out the legislative position.

Updated at 12.41pm GMT

12.36pm GMT

Justine Greening. the Tory pro-European, says the Commons voted to rule out a no-deal Brexit. She says the government cannot just pick and choose which votes it accepts.

Barclay says he has just set out the position as agreed by cabinet, and the legal position.

He says the Commons vote two weeks ago, for the Caroline Spelman amendment, does not change government policy.

Updated at 12.42pm GMT

12.35pm GMT

Yvette Cooper, the Labour MP, asks Barclay if he is saying that the government will really go ahead with a no-deal Brexit on 29 March, regardless. She says this would have damaging security consequences.

Barclay says the government’s position has not changed. It is committed to getting a deal, he says.

He says he thinks a no-deal Brexit would be disruptive – more so than some of his colleagues.

But the legal position is that the UK will leave on 29 March, he says.

Updated at 12.43pm GMT

12.33pm GMT

Stephen Barclay opens Brexit debate

Stephen Barclay, the Brexit secretary, is opening the debate now.

Here is Sky’s Kate McCann on an exchange Barclay had with David Davis, the former Brexit secretary, a few minutes ago.

12.27pm GMT

May facing possible defeat on motion saying no-deal economic impact assessment must be published

John Bercow’s decision to call the Anna Soubry amendment is significant, because its supporters think they have enough votes to get it through. These are from Labour’s Chuka Umunna, who is a co-backer of the amendment with Soubry.

And this is from Dan Sabbagh.

12.22pm GMT

Bercow calls three amendments, but none of the second referendum or indicative votes ones

John Bercow, the speaker, says he is calling three amendments: Labour’s, the SNP’s and Anna Soubry’s. (See 10.45am.)

That means there will not be a vote on an amendment proposing a second referendum, or on an amendment proposing indicative votes.

12.19pm GMT

The business motion for the debate has gone through on the nod.

12.18pm GMT

Labour’s Seema Malhotra makes a point of order, and suggests Theresa May should be here to open the debate, or at least listen to the opening of the debate, in person.

Bercow says there is no need for May to be here.

12.14pm GMT

Labour’s Angela Eagle is raising a point of order about today’s debate. She says people say today’s motion is non-binding. But when she first became an MP, the government took all motions seriously. She says she deplores the way people are now trying to claim some motions are binding and some are not.

Sir Bernard Jenkin, the chair of the Commons public administration and constitutional affairs committee, says his committee produced a report on this very subject.

John Bercow, the Speaker, says he is conscious of a concern on this front. Ken Clarke, the father of the house, has said the same, based on his 48 years’ experience in the Commons. Bercow says some votes are just an expression of opinion, and some are genuinely binding; they are orders, “effective” on the government. He says there will be a debate today, and subsequent debates too. If there is an appetite in the Commons for further debate, “that appetite will be met”, he says.

Ken Clarke rises. He says he accepts the point about different types of motion, but he says a vote that expresses the views of the Commons on a matter of policy should be binding.

Updated at 12.38pm GMT

12.02pm GMT

The Brexit debate will start very soon. John Bercow, the Speaker, is just taking points of order first.

Updated at 12.38pm GMT

12.01pm GMT

Members of the European Research Group do not always agree on political tactics and they may well split today. At the moment they are saying different things. I have been told just now by one of them that the ERG will decide later at a meeting how it will vote. But others are saying it will abstain.

11.56am GMT

This is from Nikki da Costa, a former director of legislative affairs at Number 10, on today’s debate.

Updated at 12.07pm GMT

11.54am GMT

This is from the Mail’s Jason Groves.

11.38am GMT

At the lobby briefing this morning Downing Street restated its call for MPs to back the government motion, to show Brussels parliament has united around a position, the Mirror’s Pippa Crerar reports. And it insisted that a no-deal Brexit was still an option, despite MPs voting to reject this two weeks ago.

11.32am GMT

On BBC News this morning Sir Bernard Jenkin, a leading Tory Brexiter and a supporter of the European Research Group, criticised Downing Street for not consulting Conservative backbenchers before tabling today’s motion. “The lack of consultation has not improved the atmosphere of trust,” he said.

From the other end of the Conservative spectrum on Europe, Nicky Morgan, who is planning to vote for the government this afternoon, is making exactly the same point.

11.08am GMT

This is from Labour’s Seema Malhotra.

11.03am GMT

This morning the Guardian splashed on a story saying Jeremy Corbyn faces up to 10 resignations from the Labour frontbench if he fails to back a second referendum.

In a blog that is attracting considerable interest at Westminster this morning, the BBC’s Laura Kuenssberg says the looming Labour split may come very soon. Although, as she also points out, it may not ....

Here is an extract.

It’s no secret that a small group of Labour MPs has been discussing for many months whether to leave the party, and if so, when and how.

For any MP, this is a huge decision. For many of them, whatever their tribe, their political party is like part of their family, certainly a huge part of the fabric of their lives.

But there’s a rising expectation that under stress, a small-ish group of Labour MPs might be ready to say goodbye to that, and quite soon ...

Some of those involved have talked in the last 24 hours as if it is inevitably going to happen, and maybe in the next few days. Others are far more cagey, and are dousing expectations.

But there is a detectable sense among those who have been discussing departure for many many months, that if they are ever going to do it, then the moment is coming soon, perhaps very, very soon.

10.45am GMT

Full list of Brexit amendments on the order paper

There are now 10 proper amendments to the government’s Brexit motion on the Commons order paper (pdf), plus an amendment to the Labour amendment. Here is a quick list summarising them:

1) The Labour amendment setting 27 February as the deadline for Theresa May to get a deal.

2) A Ken Clarke amendment saying there should be a ballot, allowing MPs to choose from a range of Brext options using the alternative vote system (ie, with the least popular being eliminated, until one option has got more than 50% support).

3) An Angus Brendan MacNeil amendment saying article 50 should be revoked.

4) An Anna Soubry amendment saying the government should publish its official advice about the impact of a no-deal Brexit.

5) A Sarah Wollaston amendment saying MPs should vote on various Brexit options, and that if more than one is approved, all approved options should be put to the public in a referendum.

6) A Plaid Cymru amendment calling for an extension of article 50 and a referendum.

7) The Geraint Davies amendment backing a deal, subject to changes in line with Labour’s demands and subject to it being put to the public in a referendum.

8) The SNP amendment calling for article 50 to be delayed for at least three months.

9) A Lib Dem amendment saying, if there is no deal by 27 February, May should ask to extend article 50 to allow for a referendum.

10) The Roger Godsiff amendment calling for a three-option referendum.

We probably won’t find out which amendments are going to be called (ie, put to a vote) until the start of the debate. It is up to John Bercow, the speaker, to decide. He will call the Labour one and then probably several others (perhaps Anna Soubry’s, the SNP’s, and either Ken Clarke or Sarah Wollaston’s, but that is just my guess).

10.13am GMT

The SNP’s Westminster leader Ian Blackford has been explaining why the party has tabled an amendment to today’s motion requiring the UK government to begin immediate negotiations with the European council to extend article 50 by no less than three months. He told BBC Scotland’s Good Morning Scotland programme that it was “the height of irresponsibility to be dangling this threat of crashing out without a deal”.

He added: “Parliament has the chance to instruct the government to act and it must do so.”

Meanwhile, the first minster, Nicola Sturgeon, has said that the Scottish government has stepped up its preparations for a no-deal Brexit.

Speaking after a meeting of the Scottish cabinet in Glasgow yesterday, she told BBC Scotland that it was “reckless and negligent” for the UK government to refuse to rule out no-deal, adding:

But we appear to be dealing with a UK government that’s prepared to act recklessly and negligently.

Therefore as of today we have stepped up our no-deal planning. We don’t think it should be inevitable, we’ll do everything in our power to help rule that out.

But we would not be doing our job properly if we didn’t properly plan as best we can, because not all of the consequences will be able to be mitigated.

10.05am GMT

ERG deputy chair Steve Baker says compromising on no deal would be 'daftest negotiating strategy'

Steve Baker, the former Brexit minister who is now deputy chairman of the European Research Group, which represents around 50 hardline Tory Brexiters who are threatening not to back the government this afternoon, has responded to Liam Fox’s claim (see 9.19am) that they will undermine the government’s negotiating strategy if they rebel.

There is an inherent contradiction in Baker’s argument. On the one hand, he is implying that today’s vote does not really matter: “non-binding motion”, “storm in a teacup”, are the EU really watching anyway? (Actually, they are; the key EU players are following domestic UK politics very, very closely at the moment.) But, on the other hand, he is saying that even implicitly agreeing that a no-deal Brexit is not an option is unacceptable.

9.51am GMT

Dutch PM Mark Rutte says after Brexit UK will be 'too small to appear on world stage on its own'

Mark Rutte, the Dutch prime minister, has given an interview to the Spanish newspaper El Pais in the course of which he said that Brexit would leave the UK a middling economy stuck in the Atlantic, “too small to appear on the world stage on its own”.

Here are the key extracts.

P. El Brexit ha sido la otra gran sacudida. Hay quien interpreta que la UE quedará debilitada con la salida de Reino Unido.

R. Quien va a salir debilitado del Brexit es Reino Unido. Ya se está debilitando, es un país menguante si se compara a hace dos o tres años. Se va a convertir en una economía de tamaño intermedio en un lugar del océano Atlántico. No es ni EE UU ni la UE. Es demasiado pequeño para presentarse en la escena mundial por sí solo.

P. ¿Cree que se puede alcanzar un acuerdo antes del 29 de marzo?

R. Mi impresión es que la bola avanza hacia el precipicio y todo el mundo grita que se pare, pero nadie hace nada para pararla, al menos, desde el lado británico. Algunos parlamentarios británicos dicen que queremos atraparles en un limbo permanente. Pero no es verdad. A la UE le interesa pasar cuanto antes a la siguiente fase y comenzar una nueva relación con Reino Unido. Pero dado el empeño de May en renegociar la salvaguarda irlandesa, no sé cómo va a terminar esto y si podremos evitar un Brexit duro, que sería devastador para Reino Unido.

And here is a translation, mostly from Google Translate, but with some tidying up from me to make it more colloquial.

Q: Brexit has been the other great shock. Some people think that the EU will be weakened by the departure of the United Kingdom.

A: It is the UK that will be weakened. It is already weakening; it is on the wane compared to two or three years ago. It is going to become a middling economy stuck in the Atlantic Ocean. It is neither the US nor the EU. It is too small to appear on the world stage on its own.

Q: Do you think an agreement can be reached before March 29?

A: My impression is that the ball is advancing towards the precipice and everyone is screaming stop, but nobody is doing anything to prevent it, at least from the British side. Some British parliamentarians say that we want to trap them in a permanent limbo. But it is not true. The EU is interested in moving to the next phase as soon as possible and starting a new relationship with the United Kingdom. But given May’s efforts to renegotiate the Irish backstop, I do not know how this will end and whether we can avoid a hard Brexit. It would be devastating for the UK.

Remember, the Netherlands is one of the UK’s closest allies in the EU (a point that Rutte also makes in the interview, when he says the departure of the UK means his country will have to replace it as the leading champion of free trade and open markets in the union).

The Sun’s Nick Gutteridge says that Rutte’s comments are partly explained by Dutch domestic politics.

Updated at 9.52am GMT

9.28am GMT

This is what Donald Tusk, the president of the European council, posted on Twitter last night.

9.19am GMT

Liam Fox tells potential Tory rebels they will undermine PM's negotiation if she loses key vote

With another big Brexit debate coming today, you could be forgiven for getting confused over what all these debates and votes are about. So, as a public service, here is quick recap.

There are two sorts of Brexit debate on the schedule at the moment: a so-called “meaningful vote” (MV), a vote intended to approve a deal with the EU; and what some are calling a “next steps” (NS) debate, a debate scheduled because the MV was not passed, allowing MPs to vote on amendments about what should happen next, or “plan B”.

We have had one MV so far. That was on 15 January, and it led to Theresa May’s deal being voted down by a record majority of 230. And we have had one NS debate on 29 January, which led to May winning a vote on the Brady amendment (saying her deal should be passed, subject to the backstop being replaced) but losing a vote on the Spelman amendment (a non-binding one ruling out no deal).

Today we have got NS2. As Rowena Mason reports in her overnight preview (see below) May faces the risk of defeat on the main motion because Tory Brexiters in the European Research Group may not support her. A defeat would have no direct, practical effect, but it would nevertheless amount to a serious setback. After NS1, May was able to tell the EU that she had secured a Commons majority for at least something. A defeat today would imply that that majority has gone, which could leave Brussels wondering whether May is in a position to get anything through parliament.

Related: Hardline Brexiters threaten to vote down Theresa May's motion

In this process MV debates are more important than NS ones. Today’s NS vote (NS2) could turn out to be quite significant, but NS3, which is due to take place on Wednesday 27 February, will be much more decisive, because this will be when Tory pro-Europeans could unite with the opposition to pass the Yvette Cooper amendment designed to allow MPs to vote to rule out a no-deal Brexit. This may also be the moment when Labour frontbenchers resign if Jeremy Corbyn does not firmly back a second referendum.

With most observers now thinking MV2 will not take place until March, possibly after the EU summit and only days before Brexit day on 29 March, there is also a chance that we may even get NS4 or NS5 debates in early March too.

I hope that’s all clear.

Downing Street is still hoping to persuade the ERG to back the government in the vote this afternoon. On the Today programme this morning Liam Fox, the Brexiter international trade secretary said that if Tories did not back May, they would undermine her in the Brexit negotiations with Brussels.

He said that some MPs saw voting as an “academic and ideological purity exercise” but that in reality this was about “the raw politics of negotiation and ... about sending signals about continuity and trustworthiness in negotiation.” He explained:

What we say is looked at and listened to by those that we are negotiating with. They will be looking to see whether parliament is showing consistency because in the debates and the votes we had recently there were two things: one was that parliament said we don’t want there to be no deal, and that we will sign up to the prime minister’s deal if we are able to get changes to the Irish backstop.

Our European partners will be watching our debate and listening today to see if they get the impression that if they were to make those concessions, parliament would definitely deliver on that ...

I think that there’s a danger that we send the wrong signals and I think that we need to understand that the public want us to leave the European Union but they would prefer us to leave the European Union with a deal. And therefore parliament has got a duty to ensure that we send the correct signals that represent those views of the British people and represent them to those we are negotiating with.

Here is the agenda for the day.

After 10.30am: Andrea Leadsom, the leader of the Commons, announces next week’s Commons business.

11pm: Various Labour MPs are due to speak at a Love Socialism Hate Brexit event in the Commons.

After 11.30am: MPs start the Brexit debate. John Bercow, the speaker, will announce which amendments will be put to a vote.

5pm: MPs start voting on the Brexit amendments.

As usual, I will also be covering breaking political news as it happens, as well as bringing you the best reaction, comment and analysis from the web, but I expect to be focusing mostly on the Brexit debate. I will post a summary at the end of the day.

You can read all the latest Guardian politics articles here. Here is the Politico Europe round-up of this morning’s political news. And here is the PoliticsHome list of today’s top 10 must-reads.

If you want to follow me or contact me on Twitter, I’m on @AndrewSparrow.

I try to monitor the comments BTL but it is impossible to read them all. If you have a direct question, do include “Andrew” in it somewhere and I’m more likely to find it. I do try to answer questions, and if they are of general interest, I will post the question and reply ATL, although I can’t promise to do this for everyone.

If you want to attract my attention quickly, it is probably better to use Twitter.

Updated at 10.51am GMT
fields.bodyText: We’re going to close down this live blog now, so thanks for reading and commenting. Here’s a summary of the day: Theresa May suffered a humiliating defeat in the Commons over her approach to Brexit. MPs rejected her motion by a majority of 45 and, while the defeat will have no practical effect, it will make it harder for the prime minister to argue to the EU that she has a Commons majority behind her Brexit strategy. A significant number of the most hardline Eurosceptics in May’s own party abstained on the vote. The hard Brexit-supporting ERG were unhappy that the government’s motion appeared to rule out a no-deal Brexit. That led some of the more pro-EU Tories to warn her she cannot rely on the right of her party. Reacting to the defeat, Downing Street chose to point the finger at the Labour leader, Jeremy Corbyn, who opposed the government’s motion. Number 10 said Corbyn had “put partisan considerations ahead of the national interest” and voted to “make no deal more likely”. If you’d like to read more, my colleagues Rowena Mason and Jessica Elgot have the full story: Valentine’s Day plans have not prevented the ERG’s deputy chair, Steve Baker, from responding to Harrington’s comments. This from ITV News’ Paul Brand: The business minister, Richard Harrington, has accused members of the Tory European Research Group (ERG) of “treachery” over Brexit. Harrington hit out at the ERG, which is headed by Jacob Rees-Mogg, as he suggested members should defect to Nigel Farage’s new party because they are not Conservatives. Referring to the ERG, the minister told the House magazine: The prime minister has done a pretty good job of standing up to them up till now, but they were drinking champagne to celebrate her losing her deal and I regard that as being treachery. I read that Nigel Farage is setting up a new party called ‘Brexit’ and, if I were them, I’d be looking at that because that seems to reflect their views more than the Conservative party does. They should read carefully what that party’s got to offer, because in my view they’re not Conservatives.
