I try to monitor the comments BTL but it is impossible to read them all. If you have a direct question, do include “Andrew” in it somewhere and I’m more likely to find it. I do try to answer questions, and if they are of general interest, I will post the question and reply ATL, although I can’t promise to do this for everyone.

If you want to attract my attention quickly, it is probably better to use Twitter.

Updated at 8.30am GMT
fields.bodyText: Julian Smith, the government chief whip, is meeting Tory Brexiters from the European Research Group in the hope of finding a way of getting them to vote for Theresa May’s Brexit motion tomorrow. They have been threatening not to back it, creating the risk that May could suffer a defeat that would have no direct, practical impact but that would nevertheless undermine May’s already-much-weakened credibility with the EU. Sir Keir Starmer, the shadow Brexit secretary, has said that Labour’s priority in the vote tomorrow is to introduce a “hard stop” into the Brexit process. He was referring to the Labour amendment, which says by 27 February there should either be a vote on a revised deal, or else a minister should “make a written statement declaring that there is no longer an agreement in principle in the negotiations with the European Union” and table an amendable motion on “how the government proposes to proceed.” Commenting on this, Starmer said: At the moment, the battle this week is to stop the prime minister running down the clock and put a hard stop into the process. Our amendment says there should be a hard stop on February 26. The prime minister must either put up her deal or allow parliament to take control. Speaking after talks with Stephen Barclay, the Brexit secretary, and David Lidington, the Cabinet Office minister, Starmer also said that it would be “difficult” to make progress in the cross-party talks unless May abandoned her red lines, but that further talks were planned. He said: We had frank and serious discussions. We set out the Labour party position, which is the two options of on the one hand a close economic relationship, on the other a public vote. Obviously, the question of the red lines came up, because unless the red lines change it’s very difficult to make progress. It was against the backdrop of the prime minister running down the clock. We’ve agreed to meet again to continue the discussions, so that’ll happen in the coming days or weeks. The People’s Vote campaign has said it is not backing a move by the Labour MP Geraint Davies to amend the Brexit motion tomorrow to say that May’s plan should be passed subject to it being put to the public in a referendum. (See 4.31pm and 4.35pm.) Ford has warned that leaving the EU without a deal next month would be “catastrophic” for the UK’s auto industry. As the Press Association reports, the company did not confirm a newspaper report that it was stepping up preparations to move production out of the UK. But a Ford spokesman said: We have long urged the UK government and parliament to work together to avoid the country leaving the EU on a no-deal, hard Brexit basis on March 29. Such a situation would be catastrophic for the UK auto industry and Ford’s manufacturing operations in the country. We will take whatever action is necessary to preserve the competitiveness of our European business. The former Labour MP and justice campaigner Chris Mullin has named two of the four men he believes were responsible for the 1974 IRA Birmingham pub bombings. That’s all from me for today. We hope to keep comments open until about 6pm. Thanks for all those submitted so far. Julian Smith, the chief whip, is meeting members of the European Research Group to discuss what might be done to get ERG members to lift their objections to voting for the government’s Brexit motion tomorrow. (See 11.36am.) This is from HuffPost’s Arj Singh. A secret nuclear bunker under Whitehall could delay a restoration project on the parliamentary estate, MPs have warned. As the Press Association reports, the crisis command centre under the Ministry of Defence is at the centre of concerns over the planned use of the department’s car park for work on Richmond House. MPs plan to use 79 Whitehall as a temporary debating chamber when they decant from the Palace of Westminster as part of a 5 billion restoration project. Commons Leader Andrea Leadsom, appearing before the joint committee on the draft parliamentary buildings bill, said she “deeply” regrets costs are already being incurred redrawing plans to exclude the MoD car park and she has tried “extremely hard” to resolve the issue. Lord Blunkett, the former Labour cabinet minister and a member of the committee, said: Let’s be clear so that we don’t mislead anybody: we all know that there’s been a bunker under there, we’ve known that there’s one in Gloucestershire as well. I used to say when I was home secretary, the last place on God’s Earth I’d want to be, let alone take my family, would be the bunker under the MoD. I mean it is insane. People have just got to get real on this and come into the real world. A further £5.5m of public money will be spent on the failed Garden Bridge project, it has been revealed. As the Press Association reports, Transport for London (TfL) said the money is needed to meet the cost of winding up the charity set up to build and run the crossing in the centre of the English capital. This will bring the amount spent by the public sector to around £43m, consisting of £24m from TfL and £19m from the Department for Transport. The Sinn Fein leader, Mary Lou McDonald, met Jeremy Corbyn at Westminster today to discuss Brexit. Afterwards she said: We are of one mind in terms of protecting the Good Friday agreement. In terms of the need for a backstop, we have said to him that there is a backstop, it is the backstop, it is the only backstop that there is. And that it represents the bottom line for us. He has heard that message very, very clearly. The People’s Vote campaign is not backing the Geraint Davies amendment (see 4.31pm), according to Business Insider’s Adam Payne. The Labour MP Geraint Davies has tabled an amendment to the Brexit motion for tomorrow urging the government to make concessions that would enable Labour MPs to back Theresa May’s Brexit deal. The main one would be to make the deal subject to a referendum (with the options being the deal, or remain), but it also says that article 50 should be extended, that the government should commit to matching any EU plan to enhance workers’ rights after Brexit (“dynamic alignment”, in the jargon), and permanent customs union membership being an option. This is in effect the same plan as the one proposed by the Labour MPs Phi Wilson and Peter Kyle. Kyle asked Theresa May about this at PMQs. (See 12.42pm.) If it gets put to a vote, the government will reject this plan firmly. But it would pose more of a challenge for Labour. Much of what it proposes is a Labour Brexit. But Jeremy Corbyn has also made it clear that his preference is for a Brexit on Labour terms that does not have to be endorsed by a second referendum. Whether John Bercow, the speaker, decides to call the amendment or not tomorrow will depend in part on how much support it gets (ie, how many MPs sign it). At this point, that is not at all clear. This is from BuzzFeed’s Alex Wickham. One of the amendments to the government’s Brexit motion tomorrow has been tabled by the Conservative pro-European, Anna Soubry. (See 10.54am.) It instructs the government to publish its most recent assessment of the impact of a no-deal Brexit on business. A few minutes ago Soubry told BBC News why she tabled it. She said: I’m told that the civil service, at the behest of the cabinet, has looked at the implications on trade and business if we were to leave the European Union, crashing out without a deal. And I am told that it does not mince its words, and it makes it very plain that that outcome would be disastrous, in the words of the business secretary, Greg Clark, “ruinous” for British business, if we leave without a deal. And I want the government to publish that paper. It’s been to cabinet. I’m told that some members of the cabinet argued that it should be published. They were overruled. In all the circumstances, I think it is absolutely critical. My constituents, not just business but everybody in my constituency, and of course across the country, has a right to know and understand the consequences of Mrs May’s decision not to take that calamitous outcome off the table. Here is my colleague Heather Stewart on the Conservative/Labour Brexit talks. Here are two assessments of thinking in Brussels on Brexit that are worth reading. Mujtaba Rahman, the former European commission official who is now a managing director at the Eurasia Group consultancy, says the EU now does not think this will be resolved until the March summit. Here are the conclusions from his latest assessment. And here is an extract from his assessment. May’s overtures to Jeremy Corbyn did not come as a surprise in Brussels—many see Labour’s support as inevitable if May is to muster a Commons majority—but May’s outreach is now seen as more of a tactical than genuine move. Says one seasoned EU negotiator in Brussels, “In the EU’s eyes, these types of problems always require a national consensus and cross-party majority, but we now realise this is not in the genes or culture of UK politics.” Yet rather than concluding that May is preparing to drive the UK off a cliff, the assessment being reached in Brussels and many of the EU’s 27 capitals is different—namely, that if May is to compromise with Labour and threaten splitting her own party, she is only likely to do so at the very last minute. The stage is therefore being set for a high-stakes European council on 21-22 March. Another senior EU negotiator remarks, “If anything happens on substance and timing, it has to happen at the European council.” This is because any move on substance —within or outside the withdrawal agreement—will now be politically painful and will “have to be taken by EU leaders”, as will signing off an extension of article 50. Moreover, many officials in Brussels don’t think enough progress will be made between now and the scheduled March summit to justify an ad-hoc council. Says another official, “We can only mobilise leaders if we know we’re going to make a deal. Right now, the elements are not in place for a summit.” And here is a Twitter thread from the Sun’s Brussels correspondent, Nick Gutteridge. At the post-PMQs briefing, Jeremy Corbyn’s spokesman insisted that Labour’s preferred solution to the Brexit crisis remains a general election. As PoliticsHome’s Kevin Schofield reports, this has been seen as a rebuke to Sir Keir Starmer, the shadow Brexit secretary, who said this morning that “the only credible options now left are a close economic relationship - that’s the sort of relationship we spelt out in the letter to the prime minister last week - or a public vote.” (See 10.01am.) Downing Street is currently ruling out redrafting the Brexit motion for tomorrow’s debate, despite the Tory European Research Group saying its current wording is unacceptable. (See 11.36am and 1.41pm.) This means that there is a real risk of Theresa May being defeated, in a vote that would have no practical impact but that would nevertheless undermine her credibility with fellow EU leaders. The Belgian prime minister, Charles Michel, has said the UK’s backstop demands would “weaken the economic development of Europe”. (See 1.14pm.) Jeremy Corbyn has said that Chris Grayling’s handling of the Seaborne Freight contract sums up the “utter shambles” of the government’s no-deal Brexit planning. (See 12.56pm.) Bertie Ahern, the former Irish prime minister, has said there is “no possibility” of the Irish government accepting a time limit on the backstop. Giving evidence to the Commons Brexit committee, he said: There is no possibility of the Irish government or the Irish people saying the backstop could be time-limited. There is no hope of that, I’m afraid. I don’t see the EU changing on the withdrawal agreement, I don’t see them changing on the backstop, I don’t think the Irish government are going to change on that. The Brexit secretary, Stephen Barclay, has played down the possibility of an extension to article 50. And May herself, at PMQs, urged MPs not to believe what her Brexit adviser, Olly Robbins, reportedly said about the government wanting to leave the Commons with a choice at the end of March between backing her deal and accepting a long extension to article 50. The government’s push to roll over EU trade deals from which the UK currently benefits has yielded agreements covering only £16bn of the near-£117bn of British trade with the countries involved. The freight industry has warned of the potential for a fresh Brexit ferry fiasco after it emerged all British truckers will be required to have counter-terrorism safety security certificates to enter the European Union in the event of no deal. The biggest monthly fall for gas prices since the 1980s helped drag down UK inflation to the lowest level in two years in January as the government’s energy price cap came into effect. The shadow Brexit secretary, Keir Starmer, has called for tough rules to swiftly kick out antisemitic Labour members, following rows at a shadow cabinet meeting over the party’s backlog of complaints. Speaking in Liverpool on the final day of his visit to England, the Irish president, Michael D Higgins, called for Britain and Ireland to build on their links “irrespective of whatever happens in proximate political events”. Downing Street is not proposing to redraft the Brexit motion being debated tomorrow, despite the objections from the European Research Group. (See 11.36am.) As the Telegraph’s Jack Maidment reports, it is arguing that the Commons amendment passed two weeks ago rejecting a no-deal Brexit does not really count. One of the most surprising stories around this morning was the revelation that Theresa May told cabinet yesterday that, if you scrap the mould from the top of a jam jar, the rest will be fine to eat. She delivered the tip during a discussion on food waste, according to the Mail. According to Jeremy Corbyn’s spokesman, the Labour leader does not need to do this himself - because he never lets the jam get mouldy. This is from the Mirror’s Dan Bloom. Labour MPs will leave the party unless Jeremy Corbyn changes his stance on issues like Brexit and antisemitism, one of his backbenchers, Neil Coyle, is saying on Twitter. The prime minister of Belgium, Charles Michel, has backed a ‘no deal’ over a ‘bad deal’, despite his country’s vulnerability to a cliff-edge Brexit. “Clarity requires me to say that between a ‘no deal’ and a ‘bad deal’, I prefer a ‘no deal’, which will have the merit of clarity and responsibility”, said Michel, in comments reported today in the Belgian media. Speaking in Bruges, the Belgian PM added: The backstop is not a detail, both for guaranteeing peace in Ireland and for the integrity of the domestic market, its capacity for economic development, employment and investment. A good deal is on the table, but the British parliament is trying to take us toward a bad deal. The British parliament’s demands on the backstop would weaken the economic development of Europe, a risk for our businesses and our jobs. The comments made on Tuesday echo those of the Lithuanian president, Dalia Grtbauskaitė, who claimed last month that a no deal Brexit would be better than continued uncertainty. Fox is responding to Gardiner. He says, if Labour wants continuity, they should vote for the government’s Brexit deal. He says some countries wanted the UK to drop human rights clauses that had been in EU free trade deals. He says he has refused to do this. And he says Gardiner was wrong to claim that Fox advocated the unilateral removal of tariffs. That was a newspaper claim, Fox says. He says the government has yet to decide its policy on this. Barry Gardiner, the shadow international trade secretary, says the leaked information (see 11.45am) shows that Fox has only signed four of the many trade deals that he said would be ready one second after Brexit day. He suggests Fox has spent too much time looking for new trade deals, and too little time trying to secure the ones the UK has. He challenges Fox to rule out reducing all tariffs on imports to zero in the event of a no-deal Brexit. How can exporters send goods abroad when they do not know what tariffs will be? Liam Fox, the international trade secretary, is now responding to the UQ on trade deals. (See 11.45am.) He says the best way to provide continuity would be for MPs to vote for a Brexit deal. He says some agreements have been signed. And some mutual recognition agreements have been signed. He says other agreements are at an advanced stage. He says, for those countries where they cannot get an agreement by exit day, there will be contingency plans in case there is no deal. His department will update the House, he says. Here is the Press Association story about the May/Corbyn exchanges. Jeremy Corbyn described Theresa May’s Brexit strategy as “costly, shambolic and deliberately evasive”, saying it was summed up by the fiasco around Seaborne Freight. The Labour leader said in the Commons during PMQs that the company, which won a contract to provide extra ferry services in case of a no deal, had “no ships and no trading history”. He said the transport secretary, Chris Grayling, had told MPs last month he was “confident the firm would deliver the service”, adding: “What went wrong?” In response May said the contract went to three companies in total, with the other two making up 90% of the capacity, with both still in place. She said: “Due diligence was carried out on all of these contracts and as [Grayling] made clear earlier this week, we will continue to ensure we provide that capacity, which is important in a no deal situation.” Corbyn continued, saying that Grayling had said the Seaborne Freight contract had “no cost to the taxpayer”, but a report by the National Audit Office found that 800,000 had been spent on external consultants. He asked the PM if she wanted to: “Use this opportunity to correct the record?” May accused the Labour leader of being “late to the party”, after the issue was raised in the chamber yesterday by the SNP. She added: “When these contracts were all let, proper due diligence was carried out - that included third-party assessment of the companies that were bidding for the contracts. “There would have been a cost attached to this process, regardless of who the contracts were entered into with.” Corbyn, concluding his remarks, said: “The spectacular failure of this contract is a symptom of the utter shambles of this government and its no-deal preparations. The transport secretary ignored warnings about drones and airport security, gave a £1.4bn contract to Carillion despite warnings over their finances, he oversaw the disastrous new rail timetables last year, rail punctuality at a 13-year low and fares at a record high - that is some achievement. “Now the transport secretary is in charge of a major and vital aspect of Brexit planning. How on earth can the prime minister say she has confidence in the transport secretary?” May defended Grayling by saying he is delivering the “biggest rail investment programme since the Victorian era” before noting there were Brexit questions that Corbyn had avoided asking. She said MPs did not know if Corbyn backs a second referendum, backs a deal or backs Brexit. The PM went on: “He prefers ambiguity and playing politics to acting in the national interest. People used to say he was a conviction politician - not any more.” Ian Blackford makes a point of order at the end of PMQs. John Bercow, the speaker, allows it, but he says he hope that this won’t become a habit, by which Blackford tries to get a third question. Blackford says May inadvertently misled the House. She says the SNP had no plan for independence. But it published a white paper, he says. Bercow says Blackford has made his point. Here is a clip of Ian Blackford, the SNP leader at Westminster, at PMQs earlier. (I did not cover the questions because I was posting the snap verdict.) Labour’s Rachel Reeves asks the government to extend parental leave to the parents of children who end up in neo-natal wards. May says the government is looking at this, as well as if parental leave can be extended to women who have miscarriages. Giles Watling, a Conservative, asks May to get the government to ban the consumption of dog and cat meat. May says it is illegal to sell dog and cat meat in the UK. And there is no evidence that dog and cat meat are being consumed in this country either. Labour’s Lyn Brown asks about a drug used to treat muscular dystrophy. She asks May to intervene to ensure it is made available. May says she will get a health minister to respond. Plaid Cymru’s Liz Saville Roberts asks May to ensure that her polices work for all three countries in the UK. May reprimands her for ignoring Northern Ireland in her question. She claims she is concerned about all parts of the country. UPDATE: In the comments romeoromeotango points out that Saville Roberts did not talk about the three countries in the UK. She actually said: “When will she work with others to remake this island as three self-sufficient, thriving nations, rather than perpetuating the assumption of privilege for one?” I’m sorry I missed that distinction. Labour’s Peter Kyle says May cannot get her deal through the Commons. But she could if she promised a referendum on the deal, she says. That is what happened with the Good Friday agreement. Kyle asks May to meet him and Labour’s Phil Wilson, who are pushing an amendment proposing this. May says Kyle knows that she thinks about a second referendum. She says she will ensure they get a meeting with a minister to discuss this. Labour’s Rosie Cooper asks if the government will take back responsibility for free TV licences for the over-75s from the BBC. May says the government expects the BBC to carry on giving over-75s free TV licences. May says BBC should continue to fund free TV licences for the over-75s. UPDATE: This is from ITV’s Robert Peston. Heidi Allen, a Conservative, says she welcomes what Amber Rudd said about the link between universal credit and increasing food bank use. It is not that there has been a link, she says; there is a link. She urges May to reform the way UC operates. May says there have been a number of changes to who UC operates already. The government will continue to review it. But UC is a system that encourages people into work. The legacy system left people trapped on benefits. In response to a question about Sir Philip Green, May says there is a Whitehall committee that has the power to recommend that honours can be removed from people. Like Stephen Barclay on the Today programme, May has used PMQs to dismiss what Olly Robbins reportedly said about her Brexit strategy. PMQs - Snap verdict: One of the standard criticisms of Jeremy Corbyn at PMQs is that he avoids forensic questioning. Having posed a tough question on a topic, and received a brush off, more often than not he tends to move on to something else rather than persist. But today he went micro, rather than wide-lens, and it was a success. When the topic of the Seaborne Freight contract came up in the first question, Theresa May seemed so keen to avoid addressing it that she started reminiscing about the 1966 World Cup (the first times she has ever expressed an interest in football at the dispatch box?) before responding with the most cursory response imaginable. Corbyn kept banging away at this for the next five questions, and May’s answers throughout the whole exchange were little more than evasive or unsatisfactory. Her best answer came at the end, when she segued into a general attack on Corbyn’s Brexit inconsistencies, but it sounded irrelevant to what had gone before and failed to dispel that impression that Corbyn had stitched her up good and proper. His final broadside against Chris Grayling was effective, but his best line was probably the one questioning how May could claim that “due diligence” was performed on the Seaborne Freight contract with a straight face. Admittedly, if Labour could not win at PMQs on the battleground of Grayling’s competence, it would be in real trouble. But Corbyn rose to the occasion, and he managed reasonably persuasively to turn Grayling into an emblem of the government’s Brexit record more generally. Corbyn says Eurotunnel called this contract a secretive and flawed exercise. Taxpayers face a bill of almost £1m contesting their legal claim. He asks May if she can assure the people of Thanet will not have to pay the price for the failure of this contract. May says the government is discussing this with Thanet council. She says the DoT took this action to ensure, in the event of a no-deal situation, medicines will be able to come into this country. Corbyn does not seem to be interested in ensuring that the government can ensure medical supplies in the event of no deal. Corbyn says the government should take no deal off the table, as the House said in its recent vote. He says this illustrates the spectacular failure of government planning. Attacking Grayling’s record, she asks how on earth May can have confidence in him. May says Grayling is delivering the biggest investment in rail since the Victorian era. Corbyn wanted to focus his questions on this, rather than ask about Brexit generally, because there are a number of issues on which Labour can’t give answers. We don’t know if Corbyn backs a second referendum, or even if he backs Brexit. People used to say he was a conviction politician; not any more. Corbyn says he is surprised that May can say “due diligence” was carried out with a straight face. May says, on the basis of what Corbyn is saying, contracts should never be offered to start-up companies. She says in the past Corbyn attacked spending on no-deal planning. Corbyn says govenrment advisers were instructed to restrict their due diligence checks to what Seaborne Freight told them. Some of those directors would not pass a due diligence test, he says. He says an FoI request shows Grayling breached standard rules for these contracts. What will May do about this? May defends the way the contract was awarded. She says no money has been paid to that contractor. Corbyn has stood here time and time again and said the government should not be spending money on a no-deal Brexit. Jeremy Corbyn starts by expressing condolences to the family of the army cadet who died at Sandhurst. He says he hopes cadets are offered better support in future. He also pays tribute to Gordon Banks. He says he remembers England’s World Cup victory with joy. He says nothing illustrates the flaws in the government’s handling of Brexit more than the Seaborne Freight fiasco. Chris Grayling defended this contract, before it was abandoned. What went wrong? May also accepts the need for better mental health support at Sandhurst, and she says she too remembers the 1966 World Cup victory. She says other firms will provide ferry capacity. Corbyn says Grayling said that the taxpayer would not lose out from the Seaborne Freight contract. But £800,000 was spent on consultants. May says the SNP asked about this yesterday. The money would have been spent by consultants whoever got the contract. Helen Whately, a Conservative, asks about the first conviction for female genital mutilation last month. She asks May to make government time for the bill that was blocked by the Tory Sir Christopher Chope intended to crack down on this. May says the government will make time for this bill. Theresa May starts by saying MPs will pay tribute to Sir David Natzler, who is retiring as clerk of the Commons, later today. She gives her own tribute, thanks him for his work, and wishes him the best for the future. From my colleague Heather Stewart PMQs is starting in a moment. Here is the order paper. A no-deal Brexit would lead to a “major dislocation” to the Scottish economy, according to the country’s chief economist. As the Press Association reports, In a State of the Economy report published today Scotland’s chief economic adviser, Gary Gillespie, indicated that disruptions to logistics, supply, trade, investment, migration and market confidence could cause a “significant structural change in the economy”. The analysis suggested that although the country had experienced a “positive year” economically, with growth in areas such as exports and high labour market performance, uncertainty around the UK’s withdrawal from the EU remained a “live risk”. There is an urgent question after PMQs about the government’s failure to carry over most of the existing EU trade deals that benefit the UK in time for Brexit. The UQ was prompted by this story in today’s Sun. Here is an extract. The government has promised to rollover 40 current EU free trade deals with 70 different countries, so they will still apply to the UK under a no deal Brexit. But a secret tally leaked to The Sun has revealed that just a handful will be ready in time when the UK leaves on March 29 ... A minister told The Sun: “We’re not going to get many of the deals over the line in time now. “What we hope to have instead is letters of understanding with all the remaining countries, which will go some way to reassuring business.” The current tally drawn up by the Department for International Trade lists progress of the 40 deal rollovers in four colour-coded tables. Only six are in green table, signifying they will be done by March 29. They are the four already agreed, with Switzerland – signed on Monday - Chile, an Eastern and Southern African block, and the Faroe Islands. In addition, deals with Israel and the Palestinian Authority are “on track”. And here is a fuller version of the story by my colleague Richard Partington. Mark Francois, vice chair of the European Research Group, which represents around 50 Tory MPs pushing for a harder Brexit, has just told BBC News that the ERG will not vote for the government motion on Brexit tomorrow night because it implicitly rules out a no-deal Brexit. He is confirming the story reported by BrexitCentral overnight. (See 10.54am.) Francois said: We cannot vote for this as it’s current configured because it rules out no deal and removes our negotiating leverage in Brussels. The prime minister, if she went through the lobbies for this tomorrow night, would be voting against the guarantees she has given in the Commons for months [that no-deal remains an option]. It is madness. ERG supporters do not always vote as a bloc, but May has such a small majority that, even if some of them were to vote against or abstain, she would be in real danger of losing. If the government were to lose the vote on the main motion, there would be no immediate consequence because the wording is relatively anodyne. But a defeat would badly damage May’s standing in Brussels, where EU leaders would conclude that there is even less support for her negotiating stance in the Commons than they previously assumed. At least after the votes on 29 January May was able to argue that she had secured a Commons majority for something. A defeat tomorrow would leave even that very modest achievement undone. Bertie Ahern, the former Irish prime minister, has been giving evidence to the Commons Brexit committee this morning. Here are some highlights from my colleague Lisa O’Carroll. Last night the government tabled the Brexit motion for debate tomorrow. It is on the order paper (pdf), starting on page 22, along with five amendments already tabled: Jeremy Corbyn’s, a Ken Clarke one proposing an indicative ballot, allowing MPs to rank their Brexit preferences in order; one from the SNP’s Angus Brendan MacNeill saying article 50 should be revoked, one from Anna Soubry saying the government should publish its advice about the impact of a no-deal Brexit on business; and one from the Labour Brexiter Roger Godsiff calling for a second referendum. Here is the text of the government motion. That this House welcomes the prime minister’s statement of 12 February 2019; reiterates its support for the approach to leaving the EU expressed by this House on 29 January 2019 and notes that discussions between the UK and the EU on the Northern Ireland backstop are ongoing. According to a story by Jonathan Isaby for the pro-Brexit website BrexitCentral, the wording of the amendment has angered MPs from the European Research Group, which represents Tories pushing for a harder Brexit. Isaby says the ERG, which has the backing of around 50 MPs, may tell its supporters not to vote for the government motion because it implicitly rules out a no-deal Brexit. He says: Far from being neutral, [the wording] means that MPs are being called upon to back a motion that would not only be endorsing the demand of Sir Graham Brady’s amendment for the backstop to be replaced, but also the other successful amendment of two weeks ago – from Dame Caroline Spelman – that states opposition to leaving the EU without a deal. I gather that there was a fiery meeting in the government whips’ office yesterday involving leading lights of the ERG during which the Tory eurosceptics indicated that they could not support a motion that ruled out the prospect of a no-deal Brexit. The ERG suggested that it be pulled and a new version tabled today. But the government whips did not acquiesce to their entreaties and ministers therefore face the prospect of potentially losing the vote tomorrow if they refuse to table an alternative motion and Labour and other opposition parties then whip their MPs to oppose the motion as currently tabled. UPDATE: Earlier I said that Roger Godsiff, who voted leave, has tabled an amendment calling for a second referendum because he hopes it will show little support for the idea in the Commons. That is certainly what some pro-referendum campaigners think. But Godsiff himself says that he is backing a second referendum partly because a majority in his constituency voted to remain in the EU, and so I have taken out that line from the paragraph above. I’m happy to make that clear. On the Today programme this morning the director of the German economic think tank IFO, Prof Gabriel Felbermayr, said that some German businesses wanted the EU offer concessions to the UK over Brexit and that the BDI, the German equivalent of the CBI, was out of step with many of its members in opposing a renegotiation. He said: [The BDI] keep to a hard line, they don’t want to weaken the commission’s negotiation position. I think that makes sense, but at the same time if you watch talk shows on TV in Germany, you see members of big businesses and business federations who do urge the Commission to make concessions and find a solution. Everyone knows that both sides would be hit quite severely by a hard Brexit. Prof Felbermayr said German companies were already “suffering” because of uncertainty ahead of Brexit. I think the EU should, as a quick-fix at least, offer to remove both the backstop and the withdrawal agreement’s current time-limit on the mobility of goods and capital, so that the provisional agreement would keep the EU and the UK in a joint customs territory association even after 2020, without making a difference between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK. The Conservative/Labour Brexit talks will resume this afternoon, the BBC’s Laura Kunessberg reports. But, on the basis of what Theresa May and Jeremy Corbyn were saying in the Commons yesterday about their respective positions, goodwill is limited and the gap between the two sides remains quite wide. Sir Keir Starmer, the shadow Brexit secretary, was also on the Today programme this morning. Here are the key points from his interview. Starmer refused to deny reports that he wanted Jeremy Corbyn’s letter to Theresa May last week, setting out Labour’s five demands for Brexit, to include a commitment to backing a second referendum if May rejected them. Starmer said he would not comment on exactly what happened in the drafting process. But there have been multiple reports saying Starmer thought a second referendum reference was going to be included, but that it was taken out by someone in Corbyn’s office, leading to a backlash from Labour pro-Europeans. For example, this is what ITV’s Robert Peston reported in a Facebook post. I am told Starmer is not the happiest member of the frontbench, to put it mildly - according to multiple sources. He had agreed that the final part of Corbyn’s letter to May would say “if you do not accept this [Brexit offer] there will be a People’s Vote”. A source tells me “LOTO [the leader of the opposition] agreed to this. But then Keir discovered after the letter had been sent and published that the People’s Vote para had gone”. Starmer “called LOTO and was told ‘oh we must have forgotten that paragraph’”. Apparently Starmer’s reaction has not been one of unbridled joy. Starmer insisted that backing a second referendum was still an option for Labour. He said: In reality, for the Labour party, the only credible options now left are a close economic relationship - that’s the sort of relationship we spelt out in the letter to the prime minister last week - or a public vote. He said Labour would back the new Yvette Cooper amendment intended to ensure that MPs get the chance to vote to block a no-deal Brexit. “We will support that,” he told Today. “The sense that this can’t be allowed to go on is growing.” Starmer’s comment triggered this response from the Labour MP Caroline Flint. Flint was one of the 14 Labour MPs who defied the whip and voted against the Cooper amendment two weeks ago also designed to give MPs the chance to vote to block a no-deal Brexit. He confirmed that the eight Labour frontbenchers who defied the whip in the vote on the previous Cooper amendment by abstaining had not been disciplined. But he rejected claims that this meant, in practice, MPs would do what they liked, regardless of what the whip said. Asked if frontbenchers who failed to vote for the new Cooper amendment would be sacked, he said: The job of deciding what people do on the whip is the chief whip’s job, along with Jeremy Corbyn. UK inflation has hit a two-year low of 1.8% in January, bringing some relief to households, my colleague Graeme Wearden reports on his business live blog. ITV’s Angus Walker released a wonderful scoop last night. He happened to find himself in a hotel bar in Brussels where he heard Olly Robbins, the government’s chief Brexit negotiator, chatting in a voice loud enough to be heard about what will happen next in the Brexit process. Assuming that Robbins was not engaged in an elaborate act of subterfuge (which seems very unlikely), there were two important revelations in what Robbins said. Robbins said that he expected the final vote on Brexit to take place at the very last minute. He talked about a decision point in “the week beginning end of March”. Presumably that would be the week beginning Monday 25 March, after the EU summit (starting on Thursday 21 March), and only four days before Brexit (Friday 29 March). This confirms what Jeremy Corbyn and many other MPs were saying in the Commons yesterday; that Theresa May is running down the clock. Robbins said that he expected MPs to be presented with a final choice between backing May’s deal and a long extension of article 50. This is also very interesting, because most of those accusing May of running down the clock were doing so on the assumption that she would end up offering MPs a choice between her deal and no deal. If Robbins is right, then May has or will conclude that a no-deal Brexit would be unacceptable. Here is Walker’s story. And here is an excerpt. Olly Robbins said that, in his view, he expects the choice for MPs to be either backing May’s deal or extending talks with the EU. He expects MPs in March to be presented with backing a reworked Brexit deal or a potentially significant delay to Brexit, he told colleagues last night. “The issue is whether Brussels is clear on the terms of extension,” he was overheard saying. “In the end they will probably just give us an extension” ... Robbins added that he thought the fear of a long extension to article 50 might focus MPs’ minds. He suggested: “... Got to make them believe that the week beginning end of March... Extension is possible but if they don’t vote for the deal then the extension is a long one...” On the Today programme this morning Stephen Barclay, the Brexit secretary, was asked if what Robbins reportedly said reflected government policy. “No,” said Barclay. He stressed that extending article 50 was not the government’s plan, and that it was not something the UK could do unilaterally anyway. But he did not sound particularly angered by the Robbins story, and he did not absolutely rule out article 50 being extended. Here is the agenda for the day. 10am: Bertie Ahern, the former Irish prime minister, gives evidence to the Commons Brexit committee. 10am: Andrea Leadsom, leader of the Commons, gives evidence to the parliamentary committee on restoration of the Palace of Westminster. 10.45am: Matt Hancock, the health secretary, gives a speech at an NHS conference. 12pm: Theresa May faces Jeremy Corbyn at PMQs. 2.30pm: Bernadette Kelly, permanent secretary at the Department for Transport, and Clare Moriarty, permanent secretary at the Department for the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs, give evidence to the Commons public accounts committee about Brexit planning. As usual, I will also be covering breaking political news as it happens, as well as bringing you the best reaction, comment and analysis from the web, but I expect to be focusing mostly on Brexit and PMQs. I plan to post at lunchtime and another when I finish, at around 5pm. You can read all the latest Guardian politics articles here. Here is the Politico Europe round-up of this morning’s political news. And here is the PoliticsHome list of today’s top 10 must-reads. If you want to follow me or contact me on Twitter, I’m on @AndrewSparrow. I try to monitor the comments BTL but it is impossible to read them all. If you have a direct question, do include “Andrew” in it somewhere and I’m more likely to find it. I do try to answer questions, and if they are of general interest, I will post the question and reply ATL, although I can’t promise to do this for everyone. If you want to attract my attention quickly, it is probably better to use Twitter.

webTitle: Eric Harrison, Manchester United’s Class of 92 coach, dies aged 81

fields.headline: Eric Harrison, Manchester United’s Class of 92 coach, dies aged 81
fields.standfirst:
• United pay tribute to ‘mentor of young players’
• Harrison helped produce Fergie’s Fledglings
fields.trailText: Eric Harrison, the coach credited with producing Manchester United’s famous Class of 92 youth side, has died at the age of 81
fields.body:
Eric Harrison, the coach credited with producing Manchester United’s famous Class of 92 youth side, has died at the age of 81.

News of his death was confirmed on Thursday by United, where Harrison spent 17 years as a youth team coach after moving from Everton in 1981.

Related: Manchester United's most influential Eric speaks

“Manchester United is extremely saddened to report that our former youth coach Eric Harrison passed away on Wednesday,” the club said. “Eric served United with distinction as a mentor of young players, including a number of prodigies who achieved great success with club and country after graduating to the first team at Old Trafford.”

Harrison, who played as a wing-half for Halifax and Hartlepool before turning to coaching on his retirement in 1972, was responsible for producing the group of players who were originally known as “Fergie’s Fledglings”, including David Beckham, Ryan Giggs, Gary Neville and Paul Scholes, who went on to play for the first team under Sir Alex Ferguson.

Neville wrote on Twitter: “We’ve lost our mentor, our coach and the man who made us. He taught us how to play, how to never give up, how important it was to win your individual battles and what we needed to do to play for Manchester United Football Club. Eric we owe you everything.”

In 2017, when Harrison was awarded an MBE for his services to football, Ferguson said: “If you wanted a teacher who would give you the right way forward, the right path, Eric was that man. He was fantastic in his time at United. When I came in as manager, I decided to keep him on the coaching staff. As I got to know him and the work he was doing, I realised it was a great decision.”

In a statement released on Thursday, Ferguson paid tribute to his long-serving member of staff. “Eric’s contribution to football and not just at Manchester United was incredible,” he said. “When I came as manager I was lucky enough to have Eric on the staff as head of youth development, so I got to see the work he did and not just with the Class of 92 but with all the young players.

“He built character and determination in those young players and prepared them for the future. He was a teacher, he gave these players a path, a choice and he only did that through his own hard work and sacrifice.

“He was able to impart that education to the young which made him one of the greatest coaches of our time. On a personal level Eric had a wicked, dry sense of humour and was straight-talking and I admired that in him.”

Beckham paid tribute to Harrison. “He was always watching and always with us every time we played, I can still hear him telling me NO MORE HOLLYWOOD PASSES,” he wrote on Instagram.

“I can still see him as we played on The Cliff training ground looking down on us either with a proud smile or a loud bang of his fist on the window knowing any minute he would be on his way down to probably advise me in the most polite way to stop playing those passes.

“More importantly he made us understand how to work hard and respect each other and not just on the pitch. We won’t forget the life lessons he gave us.”

webTitle: How the Guardian Voice Lab created a sonic identity

fields.headline: How the Guardian Voice Lab created a sonic identity
fields.standfirst: Earcons can make your voice app stand out from the crowd, so why not go the extra mile?
fields.trailText: Earcons can make your voice app stand out from the crowd, so why not go the extra mile?
fields.body:
What do ambient composer Brian Eno, jazz guitarist Stanley Jordan and the Korg Wavestation EX synthesizer have in common? Beyond a myriad of potentially witty and certainly nerdy ripostes, I’ll highlight one commonality: all three have played pivotal roles in the creation of memorable earcons. From Windows to Mac, Netflix right through to the Guardian, earcons are the sounds we hear as devices load, programs launch and shows begin, and they play a pivotal role in establishing tone and asserting a brand identity.

If you’re coming from the radio or podcast world, you’ll be familiar with how to approach designing such an asset, but for those of you coming to voice from the world of app development, it might appear a more daunting task.

Regardless of your background, this post looks to provide pointers on how you might create an earcon of your own, exploring what you want to communicate with it, and outlining how we at the Voice Lab approached the process ourselves. And should you be questioning whether there’s really a need for earcons in voice apps, I’ll explain why we think they’re worth the time and effort.

Sonic identity in under five seconds

When we decided to produce a sonic identity for the Voice Lab, we wanted to create an earcon that’s interesting, and augments the experience, but doesn’t become annoying on repeat listens. Based on what we know, earcons should best be kept short, so we gave ourselves five seconds.

We wanted the Voice Lab’s sonic brand identity to indicate experimentation and a forward-thinking approach to technology, while remaining consistent with the shared values of the Guardian. This led us to settling on synthesised electronic sounds as our initial sound palette, which, in doing so, conveniently kept costs to a minimum.

Initial sketches

If you’re creating an earcon, you’ll need an audio sequencer. Anything from GarageBand (free on Mac) through to the more professional Ableton, Logic, Cubase and Pro Tools options will suffice. From a sound design perspective, it can be quite freeing when you have five seconds. You don’t have much time, so you can keep things simple.

Loading up a synth, we began by recording two or three notes in a loop, leaving enough time at the end for the sounds to naturally disappear. Playing that loop over and over, we flicked through various synth presets to find a sound that felt a good starting point, continually moving the notes around before settling on a melody that felt right, tweaking the preset to modify the sound as we saw fit.

We didn’t want our earcon to sound rudimentary or flimsy, so the next step was to add some complexity to the initial layer of sound. A couple of questions you can ask yourself at this stage include: “Should my earcon have rich low end?” “Do I want the high end to sound crisp and sparkle?” “Should there be textures in the mid tones?” The answer in most cases will be yes to all three questions, as, when combined, these characteristics produce sounds that are perceived as full-bodied and rich, and that reflect well on your app.

So, to supplement your initial soundscape, you can add new layers of sounds, asking yourself: “What is currently missing?” Having a specific intention behind the addition of new sounds can help you avoid the trap of creating a muddy composition, caused by similar sounds competing with and drowning each other out.

Here was our first completed take, with a placeholder vocal added.

Refinement within a news context

After discussions within the team, the feedback on version one suggested that although the sonic palette was about right, there was something slightly unsettling about the melody. It communicated an unresolved feeling, which didn’t match our original intentions for the earcon. Being a news-focused organisation, it’s particularly important to get this tone right. By re-focusing on what the earcon should communicate, as well as the context in which it will be heard, we looked to build on our first version by developing the melody in a more straightforward, positive direction.

Mono versus stereo composition

Much of the early compositional work on the earcon was done in stereo, with some sounds giving a fantastic feeling of space because of their complex stereo imaging. This isn’t ideal when working for voice platforms, as many listeners will only hear your earcon in mono, dependent on the device they use. By switching to mono in your sequencer, you can accurately work on your earcon, knowing how most of the audience will ultimately hear it.

After another couple of versions created in mono, we settled on a new iteration, replacing a couple of sounds with more mono-friendly synths, while introducing new, more cheerful melodies. Plus we added additional details, piano rolls to provide a musical flourish and resolution at the end, and white noise sweeps to excite the high-end frequencies.

This is what the earcon currently sounds like, and at this point we feel it’s pretty close to achieving what we want to communicate. But has the time invested been worth it?

Not sounding like everyone else

When working in voice apps, many use the text-to-speech robot voice, with little consideration for further sound design. As a result, many actions or skills sound much the same, making it difficult for users to immediately differentiate one voice app from another, or indeed from the platform itself, as we have found in user testing.

We can’t be certain what type of speaker or device our earcon will ultimately be played on, from the Google Assistant on a phone speaker right through to high-end headphones and luxury car stereos. However, in creating a sonically rich earcon that reaches from low-end bass right through to the highest frequencies, which works well in mono, we’re giving ourselves a fighting chance of effectively conveying our brand identity and uniqueness to users, regardless of the device.

For us at the Voice Lab, the creation of our earcon required limited resources and time commitment, and so felt like time well spent. When considering the current landscape of voice actions, an earcon can provide a unique opportunity to differentiate your action from others.

Find out more about the Voice Lab’s mission or get in touch at voicelab@theguardian.com.

webTitle: What's the best Windows all-in-one or iMac for illustrators?

fields.headline: What's the best Windows all-in-one or iMac for illustrators?
fields.standfirst: AT wants to replace her MacBook Pro with an all-in-one computer with a bigger screen
fields.trailText: AT wants to replace her MacBook Pro with an all-in-one computer with a bigger screen
fields.body:
I’m an illustrator, and I’m looking to replace my old MacBook Pro with a PC. I have a budget of up to £1,500, but would love to spend less if possible (about £1,300). I mainly use Adobe Photoshop for digital painting and editing scanned artwork, InDesign and occasionally Illustrator.

For space and comfort reasons, I would ideally buy an all-in-one. I want a fast processor, lots of RAM (16GB at least) and a good screen display.

So far my research is pointing to the Lenovo ThinkCentre M920Z, but reviews suggest that the display isn’t particularly good. I was wondering if you had a better solution. TA

Last September, Bernadette, a writer and photographer, asked for a cheaper Windows alternative to her MacBook, and I was criticised for recommending that she stuck with what she knew. Guess what: I’m going to do it again. Anyone who switches either way will lose some of the benefits of years of experience, and will spend time relearning. Lost productivity is a cost.

I do understand that Apple’s prices have become a strain on creative freelances’ finances. And, obviously, there are lots of cheap Windows all-in-ones that would do a decent job for most home users. But if your career depends on something, it’s not a step to take lightly.

Lenovo vs iMac

The Lenovo is good value and stands up pretty well against the entry-level Apple iMac. Both have Intel Core i5 processors, 8GB of memory, slow 1TB hard drives and 1920 x 1080-pixel screens. The ThinkCentre has the edge thanks to its 2.8GHz six-core i5-8400 (the iMac has an older 2.3GHz dual-core i5-7360U) and slightly larger screen (23.8in vs 21.5in). At £839.99, it’s also £209 cheaper.

In addition, Lenovo will sell you four years of on-site service for an extra £51.60, where AppleCare adds £189 for three years, not on-site.

The problem is that neither machine is really what you want. I think your best choice is the 21.5in iMac with 16GB of memory and 4K Retina display for £1,429. Upgrading the slow 1TB hard drive to a 1TB Fusion drive would add £90, busting your maximum budget at £1,519. Sorry.

To be fair, these low-end iMacs are “pixel doubled” so they work like 2048 x 1152-pixel screens, but as an illustrator, you would benefit from the superior colour accuracy and extra pixel density.

The other problem with the Lenovo ThinkCentre M920Z is that while it can support a very high specification, Lenovo is only offering two pre-built systems, not ones that you can configure. However, the M920Z has two memory slots, so you could add another 8GB of RAM – or get someone to do it for you. In fact, you could upgrade it to 32GB, though that would be expensive.

The alternative is to shop around for an M920Z with a better spec. For example, you could get one with slightly faster Core i5-8500, 16GB of memory and a 256GB SSD for £1,105 from Laptops Direct or £1,201 from ebuyer.com. Unfortunately, you’d lose the Lenovo support option.

Otherwise, my pick would be the 24in touch-screen Dell Inspiron 24 5000, which you could look at in PC World. This has a Core i7-8700T, 16GB of memory, an Nvidia GeForce GTX 1050 graphics card with 4GB of memory, a 128GB SSD and a 1TB hard drive for £1,379 (or possibly less if you find a Dell deal or a discount code). The closest iMac equivalent would cost £1,789.

However, if a fairy godmother waves a magic wand, ask for a Dell Precision Workstation AIO 5720 and a 27in Dell Canvas touch-screen with pen support. I had a play with one last month. (Yes, putting 10 loudspeakers in the built-in soundbar was a little extravagant.)

All-in-one vs small form-factor

I don’t like all-in-ones (AIOs) very much because you lose the benefits of having a desktop tower, where you can upgrade or repair the PC separately from upgrading the monitor. Also, as with laptops, an AIO’s performance may be constrained by heat generation problems. You get more bangs for fewer bucks if you put a hot fast chip in a big mains-powered case.

Separately, you said you wanted a bigger screen than your laptop, but you didn’t have a lot of space. An all-in-one does solve both problems admirably.

But there is an alternative. You can attach a small form-factor (SFF) or micro form-factor (MFF) PC to the back of a monitor, as long as both support the industry standard VESA mount. This gives you much more flexibility in your hardware spec, and a wide choice of good screens.

Dell’s Optiplex 7060 MFF would do the job for £754 at ebuyer, though again, you’d have to add an extra 8GB of memory separately. (Dell’s price – £728.99 – isn’t cheaper because it doesn’t include VAT and delivery.)

Alternatively, talk to PC Specialist. They offer four ranges of mini-PCs built to order, and if you take one of the gaming options, you get a choice of nine different cases. They can probably find one that supports VESA, and you’ll get the best spec you can afford. The catch is fitting a good graphics card into a very small case.

Apple’s SFF solution is the Mac Mini. This started out as an affordable machine but the latest versions are anything but. A Mac Mini with a fast six-core i5-8500B, 16GB of not-really-expandable memory and 256GB of not-really-expandable SSD storage costs £1,279, which wouldn’t leave much for the screen.

Another laptop, perhaps?

A third alternative is to use the laptop as an SFF PC, and connect it to an external monitor and keyboard. You wouldn’t get the performance of a desktop tower, but you could still use a big high-resolution monitor.

For more on choosing a monitor, see my recent answer, Can I buy a monitor for photo editing that shows colour like print? (For the record, I just bought an LG 27UK650-W for £434.27.)

What you save on the laptop you can spend on the screen, or vice versa.

Unfortunately, the world is not awash with laptops that have 16GB of memory, except for games machines that are mostly beyond your budget. The cheapest option I can find at the moment is a silver HP Pavilion 15-cs0511sa at PC World. This has a Core i7-8550U with 16GB of RAM, a 256GB SSD and an Nvidia GeForce MX150 graphics card with 4GB of video memory for £849.

An alternative would be a 14in Lenovo ThinkPad E490 configured with a quad-core i5-8265U, 16GB of RAM and a 256GB SSD for £841.78. Upgrading to a Core i7-8565U would add £98.65 to the price, while an AMD Radeon RX 550X graphics card with 2GB of video RAM would add £91.13. The E machines are entry level and not built or tested to the same level as the ThinkPad T and X ranges, but I assume you don’t work in a hazardous environment.

As previously mentioned, the best value MacBook is the 13in MacBook Pro with a 2.3GHz dual-core i5-7360U, 8GB of memory and either 128GB (£1,249) or 256GB (£1,449) of SSD storage. A system with 16GB of memory and a 256GB SSD would therefore cost £1,629, which is almost twice the price of the ThinkPad E490. Three years of AppleCare at £249 would bump it up to £1,878.

It’s not worth dropping down to a MacBook Air. The new 2018 Air has a 1.6GHz dual-core m5 processor and a less bright screen with lower colour accuracy for £1,579 (16GB RAM/256GB SSD) – a saving of £50.

The 21.5in Retina iMac is a bargain compared with that, isn’t it?

Have you got a question? Email it to Ask.Jack@theguardian.com
